MEB was first coined as minor extractable value,
but now has been re-coin as maximal extractable value.
And maximal extractable value is this hidden power
that the block producers have.
And what this hidden power allows them to do is the ability
to arbitrarily include, exclude or reorder any transaction in the block.
Of course, this is a bit of a problem because right now,
with the introduction of MEB Boost,
we're incentivising the block producers to only care about the

the overall healthiness of the network.

But in reality, where does MEB come from?
No, MEB comes from two ways,
from either the execution layer and the application layer.
In the execution layer, it comes from the fact that, as we just saw,
that the block producers have this sort of hidden power
toward the transactions in their own will.
And basically, like, as we all know and we've seen,
data shows that they're constantly doing this.

because it is important to realise that the different trading mechanisms

one can argue that still back running is harmful because it's still taking away

you're going to like leave the reserve pool, the reserve prices of that AMM

That means that your first rate is going to create kind of like an arbitrage

And lastly, the most famous one, the sandwich attack and the one that is more
helpful to the users.
And the sandwich attacks happen because in reality you think that you're placing
a market order when you're trading on an AMM or an aggregator,
but essentially what you're doing is setting a limit order that is controlled
by your slippage tolerance.
And this is how the block producers now take advantage from you
